intro.title: Intro
intro.content: The project is defined as ORA Web, a small-scale software system for a contract manufacturing company, focusing on integrating contract production data management and efficiency. Case study scope: (Jul 2023 ‚Äì Aug 2024 ¬∑ Ongoing)

team.title: Team & My Role
clientPoints: Founded in 2019, scaled into one of the leading nutrition contract manufacturers in Auckland.
Acquired in 2025 by a China-listed company.
No in-house design team; I operated as the sole designer in cross-functional delivery.
rolePoints: Led end-to-end UX for ORA Web, from problem framing to workflow design and system structure.
Mapped contract-to-shipment processes and translated operational logic into scalable data and UI models.
Facilitated alignment across Finance, Production Planning, Warehouse/Procurement, and Management.
Worked closely with engineering to ensure feasibility and consistent status logic across views.

scope.title: System Scope
scope.content: This system spans three operational layers across the contract-to-production lifecycle:
points: Decision Makers: They read and consolidated data for timing, risk, and client decisions.
Shift/Planning Managers: They need accurate status and capacity signals to allocate work.
Operators/Executors: They need structured input and clear next-step prompts to keep data reliable.
scope.read: Read: Decide timing and client priorities.
scope.input: Input: Heavy data entry & initial validation.

summary.title: From intern to SaaS co-founder, I led end-to-end UX design to unify 4 Google Sheets + Dynamics 365 data into a single dashboard for my former employer‚Äôs 40-person office team. Secured them as a client with this solution.
summary.subtitle: When I started as an intern, I quickly identified the team‚Äôs messy workflows. That observation turned into a startup opportunity where I led end-to-end UX design, built a functional demo, and aligned with clients to deliver a dashboard that streamlined chaotic spreadsheets, integrated with Dynamics 365, secured a client contract, and laid the key groundwork for future auto-scheduling features.

context.title: Context
context.body: 40-person office team relied on Fragmented across 4 Google Sheets + Dynamics 365 for order tracking‚Äîno standard status markers, so data clashed across sheets, making it impossible to get a single source of truth.

broken_decision.title: Why Decisions Lagged
broken_decision.body: Managers couldn‚Äôt get the newest data at a glance‚Äîour workflow analysis showed 54% of spreadsheet time went to data entry, 37% to formatting changes (to flag updates), and only 9% to deleting outdated info. With no standard way to mark statuses, these formatting cues varied by department, forcing managers to cross-check multiple spreadsheets to verify data‚Äîbringing decision-making to a standstill.

impact.title: Impact by User Type
impact.body: To understand why manual formatting was so common, I mapped stakeholders into 3 engagement layers‚Äîthis helped me pinpoint exactly who struggled with what.

items.title: 01. Unify the View Filter the Noise

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Previously, core contract data was scattered across multiple unsynchronized Excel files. Teams faced frequent cross-table verification, which was time-consuming and prone to errors. Additionally, shared Excel sheets had critical flaws‚Äîaccidental edits were hard to trace, and lack of double-check mechanisms often led to inaccurate data.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: We integrated all core business data into a single master table to ensure data consistency. Role-specific views were designed: fixed columns (contract number, product name) stay visible on the left, while dynamic columns (billing for finance, scheduling for production) are switchable on the right. To address Excel‚Äôs edit flaws, all modifications require opening an edit popup via the '¬∑¬∑¬∑' menu, with mandatory confirmation, auto-generated change history, and double-check triggers.

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: A short loop video here would show: Switching between finance/production views with one click (no horizontal scrolling). Clicking '¬∑¬∑¬∑' ‚Üí 'Edit' to open the popup, filling in role-specific fields, and saving with confirmation. Small-screen adaptation: Popup automatically fits mobile/tablet screens, avoiding messy table scrolling.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: We prioritized pre-set role views over full customizability to reduce onboarding time for new users, while reserving a 'Add Custom Columns' option for power users. For editing, we traded direct table edits for a popup workflow‚Äîthis extra step ensures data security (traceable history, double-checks) which is far more critical for enterprise use than minor convenience. The popup also solves small-screen usability issues, making the dashboard accessible across devices.

items.title: 02. Guide the Workflow Structure the Input

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: The original contract and production data were managed in Excel, leading to scattered information (e.g., finance details, product specs, packaging info were stored separately). This caused frequent data entry errors, manual tracking of payment/production statuses, and made it impossible to directly reuse data for future production scheduling

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: Designed a structured, step-by-step data entry system: first collect core contract info (basic details, finance terms like deposit/pre-production/final payment with auto-status switching), then add product specs and packaging materials (supporting one-to-many relationships). Also integrated a production plan module that links machine capacity, production dates (including/excluding weekends), and compares planned vs. actual output.

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: When creating a new contract, users first fill a popup for basic & finance info (statuses like 'pending'/'in transit' auto-switch to 'overdue' if not marked as 'received' by the due date). Then they can add multiple products via another popup, define packaging materials with delivery statuses, and finally input production plans with auto-generated date tables. All data is centralized and standardized for future use.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: Step-by-step entry reduces cognitive load by letting users focus on critical info first; Auto-status switching eliminates manual tracking errors and ensures timely follow-ups; Standardized product/packaging data structure lays the foundation for automated production scheduling, avoiding rework when integrating with D365 later

items.title: 03. Reveal Capacity, Mitigate Risks & Uncover Growth Opportunties

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Factory managers relied on rough estimates to assess capacity and client risks‚Äîthey couldn‚Äôt track if top clients accounted for too much production (leaving the factory vulnerable if a big client left)Ôºå nor could they identify which production lines had unused capacity to invite existing big clients to place more orders. This led to either over-reliance on a few clients (high risk) or missed opportunities to grow revenue from existing clients.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: Designed a 3-section Client Capacity Radar: 3A (Client Capacity Trend) shows year-over-year changes in each client‚Äôs production volume (increase/decrease) and their percentage of total capacityÔºå highlighting sudden drops or spikes; 3B (Top Client Concentration) calculates the combined capacity share of the top 3 clientsÔºå making it easy to spot over-dependence risks; 3C (Client-Production Line Distribution) maps big clients‚Äô orders to specific production linesÔºå revealing underutilized lines where these clients could be encouraged to place additional orders.

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: 3A uses line charts + percentage labels to visualize client capacity trends‚Äîmanagers can hover over data points to see exact volume and change rate. 3B displays a donut chart for top 3 clients‚Äô total shareÔºå with a red alert if the share exceeds 60% (a risky threshold for factories). 3C uses a matrix table: rows are big clientsÔºå columns are production linesÔºå and color intensity shows order volume‚Äîmanagers can quickly see which lines a client hasn‚Äôt used yet.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: Visualizing client concentration helps managers proactively mitigate risks (e.g.Ôºå diversify clients if top 3 account for over 60%)Ôºå avoiding sudden production downtime; Mapping client-line distribution turns ‚Äúunused capacity‚Äù into actionable growth opportunities‚Äîinstead of chasing new clientsÔºå factories can upsell to existing trusted clients (lower acquisition cost); Combining trend data and threshold alerts makes complex capacity/risk analysis intuitiveÔºå so managers don‚Äôt need to be data experts to make decisions.

reflection.title: Adapting to Evolving Client Needs & Balancing Compatibility
reflection.body: A key takeaway is that client requirements can shift unexpectedly‚Äîeven with thorough upfront research. Initially aiming for a full contract management system, we pivoted when the client adopted Dynamics 365. Leveraging our early understanding of their core needs, we collaborated with engineering to focus solely on a customized dashboard that integrated with D365, cutting redundant features. This showed that flexible scoping, paired with foundational user research, keeps solutions aligned with clients‚Äô evolving tech stacks. It also reinforced designing for compatibility first, to avoid disrupting their new workflow.

research.title: DEPRECATED Research Findings
research.content1: Analyzing their daily manual workflow, I found that around 54% of actions were pure data input and 37% were just formatting changes‚Äîoften used as reminders or unit conversions.

user_voice.title: From Data to User Voice
user_voice.description: While the quantitative data revealed what was happening (heavy manual entry), I needed to understand the why. I traced these patterns back to the specific users to uncover the root friction behind the numbers.

quotes.text: We spend hours analyzing rows just to get a 'vague feeling' of whether we have the capacity to negotiate more orders.
I‚Äôm juggling design, ordering, and clients every day. I simply don't have time to manually fix spreadsheet formatting.
I need to add notes when things change, but I‚Äôm afraid to break the Excel formulas if I insert a new row.
It would be a game-changer if the data was linked‚Äîso I know instantly when materials or packaging actually arrive.
I constantly switch between different sheets just to verify if the information is actually correct.

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Users had to scroll horizontally repeatedly in Excel to view different data sections , causing inefficiencies, frequent misclicks, and a steep learning curve for less tech-savvy users.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: We unified all core business data into a single master table to ensure consistency. Role-specific views keep fixed columns visible on the left, while dynamic columns are switchable on the right. To prevent accidental edits from horizontal scrolling, we removed direct in-line editing on the main view‚Äîmodifications now require a dedicated action (covered in 'Guide Workflow & Structure Inputs').

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: A role-tab view lets users switch to their responsible section in one click. The left side keeps fixed common info; the right side only shows current tab-related content. This eliminates horizontal scrolling entirely.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: Each user's workflow and responsibilities are fixed‚Äîthey already rely on left-fixed columns in Excel to track core info, but still face horizontal scrolling headaches with dynamic content. Our role-based tab view builds on this habit: left columns stay fixed to match their existing practice, while tab switches replace scrolling for dynamic content. This aligns seamlessly with daily operations, cuts onboarding costs by requiring no extra training, and eliminates misclick risks from scrolling.

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Users had to manually cross-check contract changes, as single columns in Excel made it impossible to track updates for specific contracts. Also, Excel‚Äôs fixed structure meant they had to put unrelated info in random cells when dealing with temporary or new data. For users with more responsibilities, this meant going through more unrelated data to identify what was relevant.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: A tab-based, role-specific entry system balancing mandatory core data (proactive payment status/timeline tracking, seamless state transition) and flexible notes, with built-in support for 1-to-many contract-product-material relationships.

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: Users follow categorized sections, with clear labels guiding step-by-step data entry (e.g., time, status labels like "In Transit"). The system auto-determines contract status: future dates map to "Awaiting Delivery"; if a date passes and the status label remains unchanged, it auto-updates to "Overdue". This lets the system handle oversight‚Äîonly one entry is needed, and auto-reminders ensure no task is missed.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: This design continues our role-based tab approach‚Äîonce users understand this pattern, they can apply it consistently across all workflows, reducing learning curve. By aligning with their existing habit of categorizing data by role, tabbed pop-up windows let them select input sections without changing entry logic. The core rationale is to solve two key gaps without extra burden: supporting one-to-many relationships (e.g., multiple packages per product) Excel couldn‚Äôt handle, and enabling auto-consistent status switches‚Äîall while keeping the interface familiar and cohesive.

moves.headline: Reveal Capacity, Mitigate Risks and Uncover Growth

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: The client‚Äôs factory management relied on disconnected spreadsheets, leading to slow decision-making and difficulty in tracking operational performance, internal process efficiency, and customer order trends.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body:
A daily operational overview module showing real-time factory status and color-coded alerts for metric differences
An internal process optimization module with interactive charts that compare actual and target process time, filterable by production line or order type
A customer order analysis module ranking top clients by volume, plus month-over-month changes and production opportunities for key clients

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: Upon login, the client‚Äôs factory management team is greeted with the daily focus dashboard by default. Red indicators highlight any issues, and clicking these indicators pulls up detailed information. To switch between different views, simply click the role-tabs at the top. Some modules let users toggle between list view and graph view, while others support filtering by time and production line

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: To ensure a consistent user experience, we reused the role-tab switcher from previous modules‚Äîplacing clear ‚ÄúOverview,‚Äù ‚ÄúProcess,‚Äù and ‚ÄúClient Data‚Äù tabs at the dashboard‚Äôs top. Users familiar with the system can instantly navigate between views without learning new interactions. For individual widgets, consistent toggle options (list view/graph view) reinforce a unified visual language and cut cognitive load for frequent users

summary.title: London‚Äôs Rising Jewellery Star Ivy J Studio is set to shine at Paris Fashion Week‚Äîbut fragmented Emails, Spreadsheets & PDFs were slowing their high couture prep.
summary.subtitle: I built a centralized OS ready to deploy‚Äîunify customer browsing, stock & finances, cutting tool switches and freeing their team for the big show. I originally offered Ivy a custom landing page for the show. However, our conversations revealed a bigger pain: coordinating celebrity stylists through countless emails/PDFs was stealing her design time‚Ä¶ Now a bigger stage approach, she needs to find a solution that can fix it.

context.title: Fashion's Hidden Friction
context.quote: "This industry is surprisingly primitive. Even major brands you'd assume are sophisticated don't even use Excel‚Äîmaterials are just gathered everywhere." ‚Äî Ivy, Founder
context.context_body: This isn't Ivy's edge case‚Äîit's an industry gap. 78% of small jewelry businesses still run on spreadsheets. High-value pieces, tight rental windows, unique SKUs‚Äîand systems built for generic retail can't keep up. Tools like Booqable and SparkLayer exist, but they miss what luxury rental actually needs: serialized tracking, proof-of-condition workflows, and B2B stylist coordination. Ivy's designer friends share the same pain. Solve this once, and a referral pipeline opens.
context.pain_title: 78% of admin time was burned on redundant tasks:
pain_points: Rebuilding PDFs for every inventory request (4+ hrs/week)
Hunting personal photos for proof of condition

d1.title: 01. Live Date-Aware Catalog
d1.problem: Every inventory request triggered manual loops: Illustrator ‚Üí remove unavailable items ‚Üí export PDF ‚Üí send. Simple queries became 30-minute tasks.
d1.solution: One shareable link. Auto-filters by selected dates + buffer rules. Always current, zero downloads.
d1.how: Client opens catalog link ‚Üí selects rental dates. System checks each item's booking status + 2-day turnaround buffer. Unavailable items are hidden or grayed out automatically. Client browses only what's available ‚Üí submits request. Link stays live‚Äîno re-export needed for future queries.
d1.rationale: Ivy's existing habit was sharing visual assets (lookbooks). We built on that behavior with a familiar link-sharing model, but automated the filtering. This eliminated 42% of admin time instantly while keeping the client experience seamless.

d2.title: 02. Dual-Notification System
d2.problem: After approving a rental, the founder had to manually draft confirmation emails, attach invoices, and paste tracking links‚Äîrepetitive work that delayed client updates.
d2.solution: Every status change triggers two emails: one to the client, one to Ivy. The system becomes both client mailer and founder's assistant.
d2.rationale: Luxury clients expect fast, polished communication. By embedding email triggers into the reservation lifecycle, we eliminated manual drafting while maintaining brand consistency‚Äîturning a 10-minute task into zero effort.

d3.title: 03. Embed Proof Collection
d3.problem: Disputes required digging through personal photo libraries for timestamped packing shots. Trust maintenance became reactive "self-defense" instead of proactive relationship building.
d3.solution: Photo upload required before "Ship" action. Auto-timestamped, centrally stored, attached to client's shipment email.
d3.how: Ivy clicks "Ship" on a reservation. System blocks action until packing photo is uploaded. Photo is auto-timestamped and stored in the reservation record. Client receives shipment email with photo embedded as proof. On return disputes: photo is instantly retrievable‚Äîno searching.
d3.rationale: One mandatory step in the existing shipping flow prevents hours of future work. Proactive proof builds trust upfront and frees Ivy from the "proof collector" role.

d4.title: 04. Fail-Safe Request Capture
d4.problem: If a client's browser crashes or network fails mid-checkout, the lead is lost‚Äîno record, no follow-up.
d4.solution: Device fingerprinting + local backup + customer-driven recovery message. Failed requests are captured locally; clients receive an emergency recovery panel with a one-click "Copy to Clipboard" option. Ivy pastes the code into the admin console to restore the request instantly.

steps: On failure: System detects submission error and displays an Emergency Recovery Panel to the customer.
Customer action: One click generates a Base64-encoded message containing all selections (items, dates, contact info) + a fingerprint for data integrity.
Handoff: Customer copies the message and sends it to Ivy via email or DM.

Admin restore: Ivy pastes the message into the "Import Request" tool on the Reservations dashboard. System decodes, validates (Zod schema + fingerprint check), and restores the request into the normal reservation flow‚Äîready for invoicing.

d4.rationale: For high-value luxury rentals, losing a single lead is costly. This design respects both sides: customers aren't stranded ("your data is gone, re-enter everything"), and Ivy doesn't need technical skills to recover it. The fingerprint prevents duplicate submissions; the human handoff (DM/email) maintains the personal relationship that defines luxury service.

d1.title: 01. No Checkout Flow
d1.rationale: B2B luxury rentals rely on invoices, deposits, and long-term relationships -- not impulse purchases. Adding payment gateways would add maintenance and friction without reducing admin work. Instead, we automated invoice generation that matches existing client behavior, supporting relationships instead of replacing them.

d2.title: 02. Prioritize Logic Over Custom UI
d2.rationale: With a 12-day MVP timeline, we used reliable base UI components to focus resources on data logic, availability rules, evidence flows, and data persistence. For a solo founder, reliability and correctness mattered more than visual uniqueness, ensuring the system solved core pain points first.

content.heading: Building AI as a Reusable Skill
content.body: The AI import feature (URL ‚Üí structured data ‚Üí staging) wasn't just a product feature‚Äîit was a deliberate investment in capability. By building this as a modular, reusable pattern, I can now recall this approach for future projects requiring AI-assisted data ingestion. This "lab function" mindset turns side projects into compound skill assets.

content.heading: Trust as Infrastructure
content.body: Beyond proof photos, trust is built through system reliability. The recovery layer (idempotency + backup + restore codes) ensures that even technical failures don't break client relationships. This reinforced that "trust" is designable at the infrastructure level‚Äînot just the interface level.
